title: Netanyahu Calls for Unity Government After Election Deadlock
text:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Thursday there was no choice but to form a unity government with his rival, former military chief Benny Gantz, after the country’s election ended in a deadlock.

His statement came as the results of the election came into clearer focus. With 93% of the vote counted on Thursday, Mr. Netanyahu’s Likud party and Mr. Gantz’s Blue and White party were tied with enough votes for 32 seats each in the 120-seat parliament, known as the Knesset, according to an analysis by the Israel Democracy Institute, a Jerusalem think tank.

Mr. Gantz’s bloc of centrist, left-wing and Arab parties appeared set to get 55 seats, while Mr. Netanyahu’s coalition of right-wing and religious parties would get 56. Either would need the help of the small party, Yisrael Beiteinu, which looks set to get nine seats and is calling for a unity government between Likud and Blue and White.

Mr. Netanyahu’s office called Mr. Gantz to arrange a meeting on Thursday in an admission that the premier couldn’t establish the government of right-wing and religious parties that he had campaigned for.

“Benny, we must form a broad national unity government today,” Mr. Netanyahu said in a statement, addressing his rival. “The nation expects of us, from the two of us, that we’ll be responsible and work together. Therefore we should meet today, at any hour, any time.”

Mr. Netanyahu made the statement during a moment of grave political and personal peril. If he isn’t prime minister next month during a pre-trial hearing on bribery and fraud charges, he would likely have to resign from parliament if indicted. He denies the charges, and his allies had floated the idea of giving him immunity as prime minister.

Mr. Netanyahu’s statement isn’t a concession, however. He said his group of parties would go into coalition talks with Mr. Gantz as a group together. Likud and the other parties in the coalitions said they wouldn’t join any government that doesn’t include all of them.

That could pose a difficulty for talks. Avigdor Lieberman, the head of Yisrael Beiteinu, said he wouldn’t sit with any religious parties. Mr. Gantz said on the campaign trail that he wouldn’t sit in a government with Mr. Netanyahu while he is under investigation for alleged corruption.

Write to Felicia Schwartz at Felicia.Schwartz@wsj.com
description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said there was no choice but to form a unity government with his rival, former military chief Benny Gantz, after the country's election ended in a deadlock.
